head.title: Stocks Pull Back, With Dow Falling 21.79 Points

identified-content.classifier: Top/Classifieds/Job Market/Job Categories/Banking, Finance and Insurance

hedline.hl1: Stocks Pull Back, With Dow Falling 21.79 Points

block.p: The stock market pulled back yesterday, with many traders taking profits in issues that have had strong run-ups this year.

"It was a drifting market," said Robert N. Gordon, president of Twenty-First Securities Corporation. "Selling was predominant all day, but it wasn't anything major. A real correction would have been a lot more."
The stock market pulled back yesterday, with many traders taking profits in issues that have had strong run-ups this year.

"It was a drifting market," said Robert N. Gordon, president of Twenty-First Securities Corporation. "Selling was predominant all day, but it wasn't anything major. A real correction would have been a lot more."

After the market closed, the Federal Reserve announced that consumer borrowing in May rose at a faster pace than economists had expected. Consumer installment credit gained $11.5 billion for the month, led by heavy credit card use and marking the 24th straight monthly increase. Some analysts believe that this continuing spree might be a sign of economic distress if consumers are borrowing to meet their routine expenses.
The Dow Jones industrial average fell 21.79 points, to 4,680.60.

Most other major indexes also fell, with the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index dropping 2.41 points, to 554.78, and the Nasdaq composite index declining 6.41 points, to 970.22. But the American Stock Exchange market value index rose 2.88 points, to a record high of 509.05.
Declines on the New York Stock Exchange topped advances by 1,332 to 1,045. Big Board turnover fell to 376.8 million shares, from 409.7 million shares on Monday.

Paper stocks, which have jumped almost 33 percent since the end of January, tumbled yesterday. Morgan Stanley downgraded four companies in this industry from a strong buy to outperform. The companies were Mead, off 3 1/8, to 60 1/2; Champion International, off 2 3/4, to 56 1/4; Consolidated Papers, off 1/8, to 59 1/8, and Bowater, off 2 3/8, to 51 1/8. International Paper, which said its second-quarter earnings more than tripled, still came under selling pressure, with its shares dropping 4 1/8, to 86 5/8.

Auto issues also fell, partly attributable to an announcement by Chrysler late Monday that it will take a $143 million after-tax charge against its second-quarter earnings. Chrysler was down 1 1/8, to 48 7/8; Ford was off 5/8, to 32 1/4, and General Motors was off 1 1/4, to 50 1/2.

Many technology stocks, part of a group that has led the stock market for many months, were off yesterday. Advanced Micro Devices reported unexpectedly weak second-quarter profits late Monday and eased 1/4 yesterday, to 34 3/8. Microsoft declined 2 3/8, to 96 1/2; Compaq fell 1 1/8, to 45 7/8, and VMark Software dropped 5 1/8, to 15 5/8. The semiconductor industry's new orders report is scheduled to be released tomorrow.

Brokerage and other financial-services stocks sunk amid losses in the bond market, which pushed the yield on the bellwether 30-year Treasury bond to 6.58 percent, from 6.52 percent Monday. A standout was Salomon, which dropped 3 5/8, to 37 1/4, after saying that it anticipates a second-quarter loss of around $65 million.

Some issues bucked the downward trend, however. United Technologies picked up 7/8, to 81 3/8, after Prudential Securities raised its 12-month target price for the stock to $100 from $84. Sensormatic gained 1 1/4, to 25 7/8, following a report by Raymond James that upgraded the issue to a buy from neutral. And Greenbrier, which reported a sharp increase in third-quarter earnings, jumped 2 1/8, to 15.
